column1: ;datetime;id;status;activity;merit;post
0;2018-07-29 18:27:53;achow101;Staff;1512;1599;"Bitcoin Core version 0.16.2 is now available from:
<https://bitcoincore.org/bin/bitcoin-core-0.16.2/>
This is a new minor version release
column2: with various bugfixes

column1: as well as updated translations.
Please report bugs using the issue tracker at GitHub:
<https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues>
To receive security and update notifications
column2: please subscribe to:

column1: <https://bitcoincore.org/en/list/announcements/join/>
How to Upgrade
If you are running an older version
column2: shut it down. Wait until it has completely

column1: shut down (which might take a few minutes for older versions)
column2: then run the

column1: installer (on Windows) or just copy over `/Applications/Bitcoin-Qt` (on Mac)
or `bitcoind`/`bitcoin-qt` (on Linux).
The first time you run version 0.15.0 or newer
column2: your chainstate database will be converted to a

column1: new format
column2: which will take anywhere from a few minutes to half an hour

column1: depending on the speed of your machine.
Note that the block database format also changed in version 0.8.0 and there is no
automatic upgrade code from before version 0.8 to version 0.15.0 or higher. Upgrading
directly from 0.7.x and earlier without re-downloading the blockchain is not supported.
However
column2: as usual
column3: old wallet versions are still supported.

column1: Downgrading warning
Wallets created in 0.16 and later are not compatible with versions prior to 0.16
and will not work if you try to use newly created wallets in older versions. Existing
wallets that were created with older versions are not affected by this.
Compatibility
Bitcoin Core is extensively tested on multiple operating systems using
the Linux kernel
column2: macOS 10.8+
column3: and Windows Vista and later. Windows XP is not supported.

column1: Bitcoin Core should also work on most other Unix-like systems but is not
frequently tested on them.
0.16.2 change log
### Wallet
- #13622 `c04a4a5` Remove mapRequest tracking that just effects Qt display. (TheBlueMatt)
- #12905 `cfc6f74` [rpcwallet] Clamp walletpassphrase value at 100M seconds (sdaftuar)
- #13437 `ed82e71` wallet: Erase wtxOrderd wtx pointer on removeprunedfunds (MarcoFalke)
### RPC and other APIs
- #13451 `cbd2f70` rpc: expose CBlockIndex::nTx in getblock(header) (instagibbs)
- #13507 `f7401c8` RPC: Fix parameter count check for importpubkey (kristapsk)
- #13452 `6b9dc8c` rpc: have verifytxoutproof check the number of txns in proof structure (instagibbs)
- #12837 `bf1f150` rpc: fix type mistmatch in `listreceivedbyaddress` (joemphilips)
- #12743 `657dfc5` Fix csBestBlock/cvBlockChange waiting in rpc/mining (sipa)
### GUI
- #12432 `f78e7f6` [qt] send: Clear All also resets coin control options (Sjors)
- #12617 `21dd512` gui: Show messages as text not html (laanwj)
- #12793 `cf6feb7` qt: Avoid reseting on resetguisettigs=0 (MarcoFalke)
### Build system
- #13544 `9fd3e00` depends: Update Qt download url (fanquake)
- #12573 `88d1a64` Fix compilation when compiler do not support `__builtin_clz*` (532479301)
### Tests and QA
- #13061 `170b309` Make tests pass after 2020 (bmwiedemann)
- #13192 `79c4fff` [tests] Fixed intermittent failure in `p2p_sendheaders.py` (lmanners)
- #13300 `d9c5630` qa: Initialize lockstack to prevent null pointer deref (MarcoFalke)
- #13545 `e15e3a9` tests: Fix test case `streams_serializedata_xor` Remove Boost dependency. (practicalswift)
- #13304 `cbdabef` qa: Fix `wallet_listreceivedby` race (MarcoFalke)
### Miscellaneous
- #12887 `2291774` Add newlines to end of log messages (jnewbery)
- #12859 `18b0c69` Bugfix: Include <memory> for `std::unique_ptr` (luke-jr)
- #13131 `ce8aa54` Add Windows shutdown handler (ken2812221)
- #13652 `20461fc` rpc: Fix that CWallet::AbandonTransaction would leave the grandchildren
column2: etc. active (Empact)

column1: Credits
Thanks to everyone who directly contributed to this release:
- Ben Woosley
- Bernhard M. Wiedemann
- Chun Kuan Lee
- Cory Fields
- fanquake
- Gregory Sanders
- joemphilips

- Sjors Provoost
- Suhas Daftuar
- Wladimir J. van der Laan
And to those that reported security issues:
- Braydon Fuller
- Himanshu Mehta
As well as everyone that helped translating on [Transifex](https://www.transifex.com/projects/p/bitcoin/).
Note this thread will be self-moderated to keep out the spam that usually appears in these release announcement threads. (I forgot to do this on the original thread)"

3;2018-07-30 15:20:27;OmegaStarScream;Staff;1414;1101;"Quote from: aliitp on July 30
How to view my private key and secret phrase using bitcoin core ?...
Go to the console and type the following:
Code:
walletpassphrase ""your wallet passphrase"" 600
dumpprivkey [your bitcoin address]
If you don't have a password set
column2: you can proceed to the second command directly."

column1: 5;2018-08-29 20:14:10;cryptorelax;Jr. Member;56;0;is that a cold storage wallet? How long is the blockchain synchronization going on?
6;2018-08-30 09:06:43;BitCryptex;Sr. Member;322;278;"Quote from: cryptorelax on August 29
is that a cold storage wallet? How long is the blockchain synchronization going on?

The initial synchronization usually takes about 3 days. It depends on the number of connections to other nodes and your computer processing power (each block must be verified). Bitcoin Core is a software wallet which is a great choice if you don't want to buy a hardware wallet or use a paper wallet which is less convenient. Electrum is a popular alternative since you don't have to synchronize with the whole network. However
column2: you have to depend on an external server in that case."

column1: 7;2016-10-15 10:51:58;hilariousandco;Lamborghini Member;1778;1315;"Low value topics that do not encourage constructive discussion do not belong in Bitcoin Discussion. column1: If bitcoin dropped to $1
column2: what you do?

column1: What is your plan to get rich with Bitcoin?
Would it be impossible to make 14BTC by the end of the year?
if you rewarded 1btc
Please do not create any more threads asking what you will do with 1
column4: 100 bitcoins etc. Any threads that are deemed largely unimportant or unsubstantial in nature by Staff will either moved to Off Topic or trashed. Please report any threads you believe to be unsubstantial or don't meet the above criteria. Thanks."

column2: let us get a brief idea about what is AI and Blockchain.

column1: AI refers to Artificial Intelligence
column2: which is also called Machine Intelligence (MI). AI is intelligence demonstrated by machine in contrast to Natural Intelligence (NI) which is seen in humans and animals.

column1: The term artificial intelligence is applied when a machine copies cognitive functions that human relate with other humans mind
column2: such as learning and solving problems.

column1: From the functions of speech-pattern recognition to self-driving cars
column2: AIs goal is to learn and apply knowledge that is extracted from a large amount of data to make them more intelligent.

column1: According to Don & Alex Tapscott
column2: authors Blockchain Revolution
column3: The blockchain is an incorruptible digital ledger of economic transactions that can be programmed to record not just financial transactions but virtually everything of value.

column1: Blockchains main features consist of transparency
column2: security
column3: and authentication. Wherein the records are transparent and visible publicly
column4: it is secure as the data is immutable or incorruptible and authenticity refers to the verification process of the users identity.

column1: HOW CAN AI COVER BLOCKCHAINS FLAWS?
The blockchain is concerned with keeping correct data
column2: authentication
column3: and execution. Even though Blockchain is powerful it has its own limitations. Some of which are technical and others are inherited from the old minded culture of the financial services sector. The few things in which AI can cover up blockchains flaws are:

column1: 1. Energy consumption
One of the terms in blockchain is mining. Mining is a tough job and consumes a huge amount of energy to complete the task. In optimizing energy consumption
column2: AI has proven to be very efficient. If we see that efficiency
column3: it can even help the blockchain in optimizing the energy. This would help in lower investment in mining hardware.

column1: 2. Security
The blockchain is next to impossible to hack
column2: however
column3: as we go deeper
column4: the layers and applications are not that secure.  AI has been progressing at a good pace from last two years. AI can be of help to blockchain to guarantee a secure application deployment
column5: mainly given the fixed structure of the system.

column1: 3. Efficiency

column2: Deloitte estimated a total cost of $600 million for validating and sharing transactions on the blockchain.  An intelligent system might be of assistance here. It can compute on the fly the likelihood for particular nodes to be the first performing a certain task and informing the other miners to shut down efforts for the certain transaction and eventually cut down on total cost.

column1: HOW CAN BLOCKCHAIN COVER UP AIs FLAWS
1. Can Help AI to Explain Itself

AI black-box suffers from explainability problem. it cannot explain itself. Having a clear trail will increase the trustworthiness of the data and the models. It will also help to trace the machines decision-making process. So
column2: if you are not convinced about any decision is taken by the machine you can have a look at the process yourself and evaluate it.

column1: 2. Increase AI effectiveness:
AI works better when it has more data to analyze. So
column2: a secure data sharing means more data
column3: which means more models
column4: more models result in better actions  better results and better new data. The network effect is all that matter at the end of the day.

column1: 3. Reduce catastrophic risks scenario
An AI coded in a DAO with specific smart contracts will be able to only perform those actions
column2: and nothing more. There wont be additional actions taken
column3: whatever is specified will be brought into action.

column1: https://www.digixhub.com/"

column1: Well
column2: i think the example you give isn't a really good one... Human stupidity is human stupidity wether you're using the traditional banking system or bitcoin.

column1: If you're stupid enough to sign a legally binding timeshare contract
column2: it doesn't matter if you have all your funds in a traditional FIAT bank account or HODL'ing BTC
column3: you'll still be forced to pay up each and every month.

column1: That being said: bitcoin is decentral
column2: there is no central authority
column3: and it's based upon time-tested cryptographic techniques. This means that
column4: if you hold a traditional bank account
column5: a judge can just sign a piece of paper with which the timeshare company can go to your bank and force them to wire your money to their account. In a BTC world
column6: no piece of paper could ever take your BTC behind your back
column7: you'd always have to make a transaction yourself OR you'd have to fork over your private key/seed phrase/HW wallet pin code. That being said: a judge will always have ways to force you to pay your debts... I'd rather pay a timeshare company their dues instead of going to prison.

column1: The big difference lays in de decentralised part: if you use traditional banks
column2: your account details are just a row in a centralised relational database managed by the banking industry. If they get a piece of paper signed by a judge
column3: they can just edit
column4: update or delete your record in their database (with our without your knowledge/aproval).

column1: In the bitcoin world
column2: nobody but you can spend your unspent outputs (unless they have your private keys)."

column2: just timeshare fraud alone had 1.155 reported cases. It's when youre told you can go on a free holiday or get rich by joining an exclusive holiday club or timeshare programme
column3: but youre eventually forced to pay for it through small print in the contact. That is not to mention other types of fraud like identity theft etc.

column1: This gets me thinking
column2: is it safer to just have bitcoins
column3: or cryptocurrencies for that matter since it's not regulated by banks? What do you think?

column1: Bank fraud and timeshare fraud are two distinct types of fraud. In the case of bank fraud I think of a centralized institution that holds your money (a bank) and the institution or someone in it defrauds you. In that case
column2: bitcoin is arguably superior because nobody can access your bitcoin unless they have your private key. You have much more control
column3: but with that control comes more responsibility for protecting your private key and not losing it.

column1: With timeshare fraud you are essentially being duped by fraudsters into giving them your money. It's kind of like investing in a scam ICO. If you invest your bitcoin into a fraudulent scheme
column2: then arguably ordinary currency is better than bitcoin because you might have insurance or fraud protection (on your credit card for example)."

column1: 572;2018-09-07 11:14:12;oksgvardukraine2018;Jr. Member;98;5;"Crypto Giant Huobi Partners Singapore Trade Union to Promote Blockchain Skills

Huobi Group has announced a partnership with Singapores National Trading Union Congress (NTUC) Learning Hub to launch a joint effort to promote blockchain education via a series of courses focused on the nuts and bolts of blockchain and distributed ledger technology.
According to a press release shared with CCN
column2: the joint venture aims to introduce people with interest in cryptocurrency or financial technology to the core fundamentals of bitcoin and blockchains
column3: intending to exposing them to the practical uses of the worlds premier cryptocurrency.

column1: Catching Up
Research figures indicate that close to half of global top 50 universities already offer cryptocurrency and blockchain courses
column2: a number that looks set to grow as student interest snowballs in spite of the crypto industry downturn. In Q1 2018
column3: the demand for blockchain-related skills increased at an estimated 6000 percent
column4: indicating a long-term shift toward blockchain and DLT-related workplace skill requirements.

column1: As one of the most renowned institutions in Singapore with a reputation for retraining and upskilling professionals to enable them to keep up with the fast evolving global financial ecosystem
column2: NTUC sees the partnership with Huobi as a critical part of its strategy to keep Singapores workforce globally competitive. For Huobi
column3: the partnership forms part of an existing initiative announced by founder Leon Li in 2017 to use a proportion of the companys resources to boost blockchain education efforts and promote real-world use cases for blockchain technology.

column1: Under the partnership framework
column2: a range of seven-hour courses will be offered with a target of furnishing students with a working knowledge of blockchain technologys most important concepts including basic theory
column3: infrastructure
column4: smart contracts
column5: and how to store and use of cryptocurrencies.

column1: The plan is for future courses to explore how students can practically exploit the potential of bitcoin through crypto market immersion. Students will be exposed to real life trading scenarios to develop their understanding of trading strategies and how the market values bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies.
https://www.ccn.com/crypto-giant-huboi-partners-singapore-trade-union-to-promote-blockchain-skills/"

column1: 904;2018-09-12 17:39:33;Coinlove0000;Newbie;1;0;why the price will stop decreasing?

column2: actually not so much doom and gloom but rather a ""scientific"" theory for a constructive and meaningful discussion. I don't claim that the proposed theory is necessarily true but with prices going lower and lower it looks like speculation is gradually subsiding and this is what makes ground for this theory. The current decline and depreciation of cryptocurrencies doesn't look like a short-term trend
column3: which will be over in a couple of months. This is the doom and gloom part. The scientific part is that it is a natural course of events given that we are close to what can be called informational saturation. In simple language
column4: everyone already knows about crypto in general and bitcoin specifically. If they wanted to invest in crypto
column5: they already did so. If they didn't
column6: they wouldn't
column7: as simple as it gets. So what does it mean for us all? Essentially
column8: that there is little hope for bitcoin to make new all-time highs any time soon or even just local highs beyond minor rebounds. Over the long term
column9: we will be moving closer to the use value of bitcoin and other coins (if there's any in them in the first place)
column10: with the price closer to what it would be if there were no speculation at all.

column1: Please prove me wrong but don't call me vile names at that."

column1: Take the case for instance of PDAs who first sports the trusty stylus. Palm Pilot was not able to budge a bit as they face extinction even though they revolutionized the way we interact with collective data.
And how about paid emails? A very promising profitable industry that went down the drain with the advent of gmail who simply gave away nearly unlimited mailbox space.
Remember dial-up? The cranky noise it creates that nearly last a minute or so was music to our ears just to go online!
All these revolutionary technology went obsolete in just a decade or so. So there's no telling how much time blockchain and bitcoin have.
Nonetheless

column1: The number of people doing this are few are far between. 99% of transactions are speculatory in nature and this is a huge problem. Really I point to the block reward algorithm as being the main problem. It exacerbates demand shifts by also continually limiting supply more and more as time goes on. This leads to volatility and the boom and bust cycles we experience every few years. The real issues is that with every boom and bust cycle you alienate more and more people because most got in at the height of euphoria. Most of these people will not come back or trust Bitcoin in the future. That means that with each bubble there is less and less new money available."

column1: Lets be honest. Real crypto communities  there are few. There are few people who own cryptocurrency. The number is vanishingly small. Crypto prices will not grow while there are so few of us. The demand is just too small and there are no drivers of growth.
So
column2: what should we do? Is there a reason to just sit and wait for cryptocurrencies to grow? I believe there is none. The only possible solution is that people actually start using crypto in their everyday lives. The number of crypto transactions should amount to hundreds of millions a day. Then
column3: and only then
column4: will cryptocurrencies grow in price.

column1: Personally
column2: I see no other options. However
column3: this cannot be handled by one man alone. The whole crypto community should do this. You may ask: is it possible to live paying with cryptocurrencies only? Judging from our experience   yes. Moreover
column4: we have video proof: here is a story of a guy from Scotland https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Gb_yVnkHSFs and here is a story of a guy from Thailand https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=l09U16Oqbck.

column3: proud to do nothing with their cryptocurrency. But do you really believe this approach will change the world? Seriously?

column1: Lets be honest. Real crypto communities  there are few. There are few people who own cryptocurrency. The number is vanishingly small. Crypto prices will not grow while there are so few of us. The demand is just too small and there are no drivers of growth.
So
column2: what should we do? Is there a reason to just sit and wait for cryptocurrencies to grow? I believe there is none. The only possible solution is that people actually start using crypto in their everyday lives. The number of crypto transactions should amount to hundreds of millions a day. Then
column3: and only then
column4: will cryptocurrencies grow in price.

column1: Personally
column2: I see no other options. However
column3: this cannot be handled by one man alone. The whole crypto community should do this. You may ask: is it possible to live paying with cryptocurrencies only? Judging from our experience   yes. Moreover
column4: we have video proof: here is a story of a guy from Scotland https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Gb_yVnkHSFs and here is a story of a guy from Thailand https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=l09U16Oqbck.

column1: People will say Im biased

column1: Sadly

column1: What hodlers should understand is that they can achieve the same effect if they follow the strategy I outlined in this earlier post: spend & accept.
They simply have to plan a bit and keep checking their balance: approximately spend the same amount of BTC in a timeframe (e.g. per month) than the amount of BTC they get as an income.

I know that not so much people may have the opportunity to accept BTC for their work. But they could start a freelance side-project and gradually reduce hours of their regular job (if they can) and so slowly become more independent from the fiat system. Or
column2: if this is not possible
column3: the easy way: every month re-buy the same amount of BTC than they spent. That should be possible for everybody
column4: and it already helps the ecosystem.

column1: The only disadvantage is in countries like Germany where you have tax advantages if you hold your coins for more than a year. In this case I would hold exactly a year and then start the ""spend & receive"" cycle.
(I have a little hope that this thread doesn't evolve into a pure spam megathread - if yes
column2: then this is my last post here.)"

column1: Lets be honest. Real crypto communities  there are few. There are few people who own cryptocurrency. The number is vanishingly small. Crypto prices will not grow while there are so few of us. The demand is just too small and there are no drivers of growth.

column3: and only then

column3: holdlers do not contribute to demand itself
column4: all they do is decrease the supply side. But the effect is essentially the same as the aggregate demand starts to exceed the aggregate supply and then prices start to grow on a supply running dry
column5: which in turn increases volatility due to lower number of coins left in the market. On the other hand
column6: spendlers change the supply side directly either by increasing it when they sell their coins in the open market
column7: or by spending elsewhere
column8: which also ultimately leads to an increase in supply."

column1: Here is a briefly story which I have found on medium (https://medium.com/swlh/should-bitcoin-be-regulated-9e1155c1d56e) First created in 2009 by a person with the alias Satoshi Nakamoto
column2: Bitcoin became the pioneer of cryptocurrency and Blockchain technology. Bitcoin is a digital currency in which encryption and cryptography are used to control the value and verify the transactions. While traditional currency goes to central payment processors
column3: such as Visa and MasterCard
column4: Bitcoin transactions are processed by computers running special software. Every time a transaction occurs
column5: the network records both the senders and the receivers Bitcoin addresses
column6: and the amount of money into the end of a Ledger or a record called Blockchain. After nearly a decade since its invention
column7: Blockchain has not yet reached to its full potential. Billions of dollars of investments are made every day
column8: but none of the great potentials come to reality
column9: despite only serving Bitcoin for its payment system and allows illegal payments to occur in the Dark Web. The government has started to underestimate the value of Bitcoin and thinks that regulation is the best way to solve its issue. On the other side
column10: the majority Blockchain developers do not approve the regulatory framework proposed by the government
column11: as they think Blockchain will still reach to something significant in the long run. Many tech investors view the Blockchain in the future as a host for applications
column12: such as crowdfunding and online voting. Although cryptocurrencies have several downsides
column13: strict regulations from the government are not the right solution as they would decrease the market value and prevent the Blockchain from reaching its full potential
column14: such as managing personal identity and improving representative democracy.

column1: The core technology in Bitcoin which is called Blockchain is what makes Bitcoin special as many tech experts claim it to be hacker proof. Back when Bitcoin and computers have were not yet invented
column2: the most popular way for people to keep their secret documents is by keeping them in a vault and making a lot of copies. Thus
column3: when someone else stole the persons document without breaking into the vault
column4: the victim would still have other copies in different locations. Similar to Blockchain
column5: files or any pieces of information are encrypted so that only a specific person could read or write the file
column6: which are stored in thousands of computers but still linked together with the internet. The computers combine which store all the files are called node-blocks and the network connecting all the files are called chain. The encrypted code will get updated every several hours which makes the entire system almost impossible for a hacker to break in."

Its also difficult to regulate Bitcoin when
column2: in actual fact
column3: regulations vary from country to country. The only similarity may very well be those countries where cryptocurrency is banned or restricted. The issue of how it is classified also comes up again when looking at a global view of Bitcoin.

column1: In an Investopedia article
column2: a roundup of countries illustrates some of the varied regulations related to cryptocurrency. Here are some examples of the different regulations:

column1: - Australia wants to tax cryptocurrency like other commercial transactions but is also cautious after security concerns from losses in 2013.
- Brazil has enacted a law about electronic currencies and payment systems
column2: leading the way in evolving its regulations.

column1: - Canada would like to tax Bitcoin but it is currently not recognized as legal tender so as no legal recognition.
- China restricts its use and does allow financial institutions to conduct any transactions using Bitcoin.
- The European Union has spent time debating the issue and has found some ways to tie a legal basis for Bitcoin to its existing laws
column2: but the European Banking Authority is still against it until it becomes regulated.

column1: - Finland has created specific instructions on how it can be used. It also has made any gains from these transactions subject to capital gains tax.
- India has shut down the countrys largest Bitcoin trading platform and currently has no regulatory framework for cryptocurrency.
- Russia restricts the use of Bitcoin and is concerned over its potential for use in money laundering or terrorist activities.

- The UK does not currently regulate cryptocurrency but does subject profits or losses on Bitcoin trading to capital gains tax while VAT is applied to any goods that are sold in exchange for this digital currency.
Many more countries are in similar places to these listed here
column2: but these examples illustrate just how far apart the world is on reaching some type of agreement on regulations of Bitcoin.

2344;2018-09-07 16:39:27;RandyGamage;Jr. Member;126;0;"A few years ago
column2: bitcoin was a niche tech toy for nerds. Today
column3: bitcoin has grown to become a household name.

column1: The vast majority of people in the developed world have heard of bitcoin. That idea was reinforced this past week with the release of a survey from YouGov.
That survey indicated that 79% of Americans have heard of bitcoin. Additionally
column2: nearly half of millennials wish to invest in bitcoin.

column1: The online survey collected information from 2 million respondents across the United States. You can view the full study here. YouGov is an international online-based market research company headquartered in London.
Some of the most interesting facts gathered from the survey include:
- 79% of Americans are familiar with at least one kind of cryptocurrency
- 71% of Americans have heard of bitcoin
-The next-leading cryptocurrency is Ether/Ethereum
column2: with 13% of Americans claiming theyve heard of it

column1: - Men are significantly more likely than women to report hearing about a cryptocurrency: 27% of women claim
they have not heard of any cryptocurrency
column2: while 16% of men chose the same answer

column1: - Litecoin was the third most recognizable cryptocurrency
column2: with 18% of men reportedly knowing about Litecoin and 5% of women

column1: - Despite the widespread acknowledgement of bitcoin
column2: few respondents were directly involved with the worlds largest cryptocurrency; of those who had heard of bitcoin
column3: 87% have had no interaction with it
column4: which means they havent bought
column5: sold
column6: or mined bitcoin

column1: - Approximately half (49%) of respondents said they were Glad I didnt buy bitcoin earlier
column2: and I dont plan to buy it; 15%
column3: meanwhile
column4: wished they had bought bitcoin earlier
column5: but I feel like its too late now

column1: Relatively few people have any immediate plans to buy bitcoin
column2: according to the survey
column3: despite the fact that over one third (36%) of respondents believe cryptocurrency will become widely accepted

column1: - Cryptocurrencies continue to have a stigma associated with illegal transactions
column2: with 25% of respondents claiming that they believe most cryptocurrency transactions are for illegal purposes; an additional 19% said cryptocurrencies were used equally for legal and illegal purposes
column3: with 17% reporting that cryptocurrencies were used more for legal than illegal purposes

column1: - Among millennials
column2: approximately half are interested in cryptocurrency: 48% reported being interested in cryptocurrency
column3: with 50% claiming they were not interested

column1: - A narrow majority of respondents (57%) said they would not be interested in converting into crypto away from the US Dollar
column2: with one third (36%) claiming they would be interested in converting the majority of their funds to cryptocurrency

column1: Overall
column2: this study provides one of the best views of public opinion towards cryptocurrency. With 2 million respondents
column3: the YouGov survey was bigger than most other crypto surveys to date. You can take the survey results in an optimistic or pessimistic way. Optimists will point to the fact that 36% of respondents would be interested in switching their funds to crypto
column4: for example
column5: while pessimists will mention that 50% of respondents had no interest in cryptocurrency.

column1: Its also important to note that YouGov is an online data analytics company. That means the results are inevitably skewed towards representing people who are already on the internet. 79% of respondents reported knowing about bitcoin
column2: for example
column3: but those respondents are all connected to the internet. If we were to take a more representative study of America as a whole
column4: it seems unlikely that 4 in 5 would have heard of bitcoin.

column1: While the crypto landscape changes
column2: were still a long ways away from widespread adoption of cryptocurrencies as a unit of account. This survey
column3: however
column4: shows that the public is interested in crypto  or at least aware of it.

column1: Courtesy. bitcoinexchangeguide.com"

column1: 2383;2018-09-11 15:33:58;tegarp90;Full Member;406;100;"Quote from: RandyGamage on September 07
A few years ago
column2: bitcoin was a niche tech toy for nerds. Today
column3: bitcoin has grown to become a household name.

column1: The vast majority of people in the developed world have heard of bitcoin. That idea was reinforced this past week with the release of a survey from YouGov.
That survey indicated that 79% of Americans have heard of bitcoin. Additionally
column2: nearly half of millennials wish to invest in bitcoin.

column1: The online survey collected information from 2 million respondents across the United States. You can view the full study here. YouGov is an international online-based market research company headquartered in London.
Some of the most interesting facts gathered from the survey include:
- 79% of Americans are familiar with at least one kind of cryptocurrency
- 71% of Americans have heard of bitcoin
-The next-leading cryptocurrency is Ether/Ethereum
column2: with 13% of Americans claiming theyve heard of it

column1: - Men are significantly more likely than women to report hearing about a cryptocurrency: 27% of women claim
they have not heard of any cryptocurrency
column2: while 16% of men chose the same answer

column1: - Litecoin was the third most recognizable cryptocurrency
column2: with 18% of men reportedly knowing about Litecoin and 5% of women

column1: - Despite the widespread acknowledgement of bitcoin
column2: few respondents were directly involved with the worlds largest cryptocurrency; of those who had heard of bitcoin
column3: 87% have had no interaction with it
column4: which means they havent bought
column5: sold
column6: or mined bitcoin

column1: - Approximately half (49%) of respondents said they were Glad I didnt buy bitcoin earlier
column2: and I dont plan to buy it; 15%
column3: meanwhile
column4: wished they had bought bitcoin earlier
column5: but I feel like its too late now

column1: Relatively few people have any immediate plans to buy bitcoin
column2: according to the survey
column3: despite the fact that over one third (36%) of respondents believe cryptocurrency will become widely accepted

column1: - Cryptocurrencies continue to have a stigma associated with illegal transactions
column2: with 25% of respondents claiming that they believe most cryptocurrency transactions are for illegal purposes; an additional 19% said cryptocurrencies were used equally for legal and illegal purposes
column3: with 17% reporting that cryptocurrencies were used more for legal than illegal purposes

column1: - Among millennials
column2: approximately half are interested in cryptocurrency: 48% reported being interested in cryptocurrency
column3: with 50% claiming they were not interested

column1: - A narrow majority of respondents (57%) said they would not be interested in converting into crypto away from the US Dollar
column2: with one third (36%) claiming they would be interested in converting the majority of their funds to cryptocurrency

column1: Overall
column2: this study provides one of the best views of public opinion towards cryptocurrency. With 2 million respondents
column3: the YouGov survey was bigger than most other crypto surveys to date. You can take the survey results in an optimistic or pessimistic way. Optimists will point to the fact that 36% of respondents would be interested in switching their funds to crypto
column4: for example
column5: while pessimists will mention that 50% of respondents had no interest in cryptocurrency.

column1: Its also important to note that YouGov is an online data analytics company. That means the results are inevitably skewed towards representing people who are already on the internet. 79% of respondents reported knowing about bitcoin
column2: for example
column3: but those respondents are all connected to the internet. If we were to take a more representative study of America as a whole
column4: it seems unlikely that 4 in 5 would have heard of bitcoin.

column1: While the crypto landscape changes
column2: were still a long ways away from widespread adoption of cryptocurrencies as a unit of account. This survey
column3: however
column4: shows that the public is interested in crypto  or at least aware of it.

column1: Courtesy. bitcoinexchangeguide.com
Not a secret if america is the largest cryptocurrency community followed by china.
I think there are some group of american that rule the crypto movement

column3: or buy them. It's not like bitcoin was released to the public and everyone can just get as much as they can. You have to either mine it or buy (or work in exchanged of) the mined ones.

column3: you have bitcoin-the-token

column1: The system enables payments to be sent between users without passing through a central authority

Please share whatever views you are having.

I suggest you read this
column2: Tim Swanson wrote the! Why Bitcoin Needs Fiat (And This Won't Change in 2018)

column1: Tim Swanson is the director of research at Post Oak Labs
column2: a U.S.-based technology advisory firm
column3: and the former director of research at distributed ledger technology consortium R3.

column1: Imagine a parallel universe in which the U.S. economy could only grow at $50 every 10 minutes generating a mere $2.6 million of output per annum. That due to a hard-coded economic planning computer program
column2: every four years the income its inhabitants collectively generated divided in half. Such that in year nine
column3: its output shrank and was $12.50 every 10 minutes or $657
column4: 000 a year.

column1: That is to say
column2: irrespective of how productive and skilled the labor force became or how large the labor force grew
column3: the productive output in the U.S remained fixed and static with the only change (downward in this case) occurring just once every four years.

column1: How many people would volunteer to live and work in that ""Upside Down"" world?
This situation effectively mirrors the static
column2: internal economy of bitcoin and many other cryptocurrencies.

column1: For instance
column2: with proof-of-work networks like bitcoin
column3: the marginal productivity of labor is zero. It does not matter how many more units of labor are added to the income generation (mining) process as the network will always produce the same amount of economic output.

column1: Today
column2: after nearly nine years of operation
column3: the bitcoin network  better referred to as Bitcoinland  generates 12.5 bitcoins roughly every 10 minutes. Irrespective of external economic conditions
column4: of demand
column5: the Bitcoinland economy will generate about 657
column6: 000 bitcoins per year in its third epoch.

column1: While comparisons with aggregate measurements like GDP and money supplies may be an imperfect analogy
column2: the fact that economic expansion as measured in output can  with the exception of a fork and rule change  never change in bitcoin due to its inelastic coin supply is arguably detrimental to its unit of account.

column1: The purposefully planned sameness is often extolled as a ""feature not a bug
column2: and many cryptocurrency enthusiasts like to daydream for when regulators and financial institutions of our own world disappear
column3: eaten up by grey goo nanites funded by bitcoins.

column1: But before bitcoiners can reach their Upside Down nirvana state
column2: they need to resolve the underlying omnipresent economic calculation challenge facing their security system and labor force.

column1: The phenomenon is simple to describe: virtually no participant in Bitcoinland conducts economic calculations (such as pricing) for any goods or services in cryptocurrencies such as bitcoin.  There are many reasons for this
column2: including chronic volatility.

column1: ncreasingly high ($10+) transaction fees that result in hemorrhaging of merchants (even their very own Cobra Commander acknowledges this issue).
Labor force
If Bitcoinland is viewed as its own sovereign (virtual) nation-state
column2: the only wages any native participant receives in return for any kind of service rendered is what miners are paid to solve and ""vote"" on a benign problem about once every 10 minutes.

column1: From the perspective of the network: developers
column2: maintainers
column3: administrators
column4: enthusiasts
column5: Twitter sock puppets
column6: meme artisans
column7: flame war veterans
column8: self-appointed thought leaders
column9: pumpers
column10: hat wearers
column12: are all viewed as foreign third parties and can only receive bitcoins after they are first minted by the miners.

column1: Much like multinational corporations (MNC) with large overseas operations
column2: miners of cryptocurrency networks as a whole do not measure the income they receive in terms of bitcoins (or other discrete cryptocurrencies)
column3: but instead they measure their income in terms of ""fiat"" from foreign financial markets
column4: specifically converting bitcoins into the local fiat currency where their mining operation physically resides.

column1: However
column2: unlike MNCs that eventually repatriate some or all of their capital back to their headquarters
column3: aside from a recycling of coins into ICOs
column4: most cryptocurrency-focused companies are still dependent on what amounts to foreign domestic income (FDI)
column5: regular injections of foreign capital from venture firms in order to grow or even measure enterprise valuations.

column1: Miners do this because the unit of account for fiat currency is typically stable and liquid
column2: such that they can pay wages to their employees
column3: pay rent
column4: electrical costs
column5: property taxes
column6: etc. There are exceptions to stability
column7: such as planned economies of Venezuela and Zimbabwe which have suffered from years of political chaos
column8: but in general
column9: most developed countries and even developing countries have relatively stable domestic currencies relative to Bitcoinland.

column1: And because bitcoin is still not used as a unit of account
column2: its labor force (miners)
column3: rely on a third-party reference data in order to conduct all economic calculations.  That is to say
column4: in order for Bob the miner to accurately calculate if he should increase or decrease consumption (and investment) of capital
column5: or to measure whether his mining operation is profitable
column6: Bob projects future revenue based on a unit of account that is stable
column7: in this case
column8: currency from foreign capital markets.

column1: During the Cold War there was a joke in academia: that the Soviet Union would conquer the world with the exception of New Zealand (other versions used Switzerland as the cut-out). New Zealand would be left alone because the Politburo needed a functioning market so that the Soviets could know what the market prices were for goods and services.
While Bitcoinland may be attracting large sums of foreign capital
column2: miners continually still need very liquid over-the-counter (OTC) and spot exchanges denominated in foreign currencies because it is with these foreign currencies that they pay their bills.

column1: In this case
column2: despite their own defects and problems
column3: the U.S.
column4: eurozone
column5: Japan
column6: South Korea
column7: China and several other countries effectively stand in for ""New Zealand
column8: such that the national currencies and prices in these countries reflect dynamic economic conditions that bitcoin miners can use as reference rates in their capital consumption projections.

column1: Final remarks

column2: just as the past nine years
column3: miners will still depend on foreign financial markets for both stable pricing and liquidity. If the existing traditional financial markets became chaotic and unstable
column4: miners would be unable to rationally plan and allocate for future investments.

column1: For instance
column2: the unseen costs of hash generation for a hypothetically stable $20
column3: 000 bitcoin would be about $13 billion in capital consumed by miners in their rent-seeking race.

column1: And that is just one proof-of-work coin. If there were dramatic bouts of volatility
column2: or even an extended bear market
column3: this could result in bankruptcies like CoinTerra
column4: HashFast or KnC previously went through
column5: though that is beyond the speculation of this article.

column1: Ironically
column2: despite all the bluster
column3: because cryptocurrency ecosystems lack a circular flow of income
column4: they will still be dependent on the very financial system they vilify for daily support and stability.

column1: And while there have been many ""stablecoin"" projects announced and launched over the past year
column2: nearly all of them are not only dependent on commercial bank accounts
column3: but also on the economic stability of a specific economic region they aim to serve. Guess what set of entities provides that type of relative stability?

column1: Ideological enthusiasts will likely resort to whataboutisms and respond by bitcoinsplaining: how dirty filthy statists will censor your virtuous darknet market transactions and that maintaining proof-of-work networks is worth any cost to the environment! But again
column2: that is for a snarky article on a different day.

column1: Empirically with proof-of-work-based blockchains
column2: the labor force and the liquidity providers all still depend on functional
column3: mature foreign capital markets in order to convert their coins into real money. Perhaps this will change as more hedging products
column4: courtesy again of foreign financial markets
column5: are brought online.

column1: While the traditional financial markets will continue to exist and grow without having to rely on cryptocurrencies for rationally pricing domestic economic activity
column3: as in years prior
column4: Bitcoinland is still fully dependent on the stability of foreign economies providing liquidity and pricing data to the endogenous labor force of bitcoin.

column1: Source: https://www.coindesk.com/bitcoin-still-needs-fiat-currency-wont-change-2018/"

column1: Indeed. There is no escaping criticism. And what's more? Any flourishing industry will receive tons of it. Some do it to bring the market down and some do it with constructive purposes.
Therefore
column2: criticism should always be welcomed with an open mind. If the point in hand is valid and calls for improvement
column3: then it serves as a bright reminder and call to action.

column1: What is your opinion.?

column2: which is incredibly unlikely due to the cost of production of ASICs and the limited resources available. The government would have to crack down on their citizens and restrict their freedoms in order to control the network by making mining illegal (think new world order type stuff)
column3: and we would have much bigger problems if this were to happen. And if they were to do this the only thing they could do is to not accept certain transactions into a block. They wouldn't be able to do much more than that.
